title.raw: 卷一上 高帝紀上 Volume 1: Annals of Emperor Gaozu 1

sentences.zh: 高祖，沛豐邑中陽里人也，姓劉氏。

translations.literal: Gaozu was a person from Zhongyang Village, Fengyi Township, Pei County, and his surname was Liu.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu hailed from Zhongyang Village in Fengyi Township, Pei County, and bore the surname Liu.

sentences.zh: 母媼嘗息大澤之陂，夢與神遇。

translations.literal: His mother once rested by the bank of Daze Marsh, and dreamed that she encountered a god.
translations.idiomatic: His mother once rested by the shore of Daze Marsh and dreamt of meeting a divine being.

sentences.zh: 是時雷電晦冥，父太公往視，則見交龍於上。

translations.literal: At that time there was thunder and lightning, darkness and obscurity; his father Taigong went to look, and then saw two dragons mating above.
translations.idiomatic: Thunder crashed and lightning flashed in the darkened heavens; his father Taigong went to investigate and witnessed two dragons entwined above.

sentences.zh: 已而有娠，遂產高祖。

translations.literal: Soon after she became pregnant, and then gave birth to Gaozu.
translations.idiomatic: Soon after, she conceived and gave birth to Emperor Gaozu.

translations.literal: Emperor Gaozu hailed from Zhongyang Village in Fengyi Township, Pei County, and bore the surname Liu. His mother once rested by the shore of Daze Marsh and dreamt of meeting a divine being. Thunder crashed and lightning flashed in the darkened heavens; his father Taigong went to investigate and witnessed two dragons entwined above. Soon after, she conceived and gave birth to Emperor Gaozu.

sentences.zh: 高祖為人，隆準而龍顏，美須髯，左股有七十二黑子。

translations.literal: Gaozu as a person had a high nose and dragon-like face, beautiful beard and whiskers, and seventy-two black moles on his left thigh.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu had a prominent nose, a dragon-like countenance, magnificent beard and whiskers, and seventy-two black moles on his left thigh.

sentences.zh: 寬仁愛人，意豁如也。

translations.literal: He was benevolent and loved people, had an open-hearted disposition.
translations.idiomatic: He was benevolent and loved people, enjoying giving charity, and had an open-hearted disposition.

sentences.zh: 常有大度，不事家人生產作 業。

translations.literal: He constantly had great magnanimity, did not engage in household production and work.
translations.idiomatic: He always showed great magnanimity and never concerned himself with household chores or farm work.

sentences.zh: 及壯，試吏，為泗上亭長，廷中吏無所不狎侮。

translations.literal: When he grew up, he tested for office, became the pavilion chief of Sishang, and in the court among the officials there was none he did not treat with familiarity and mockery.
translations.idiomatic: When he came of age, he took the civil service examination and became the pavilion chief of Sishang. Among the officials in the county court, there was not one he did not treat with casual familiarity or mock.

sentences.zh: 好酒及色。

translations.literal: He was fond of wine and sex.
translations.idiomatic: He loved wine and women.

sentences.zh: 常從王媼、武負貰酒，時飲醉臥，武負、王媼見其上常有怪。

translations.literal: He constantly borrowed wine from Wang Po and Wu Fu, at times drank until drunk and lying down, Wu Fu and Wang Po saw that above him there was constantly something strange.
translations.idiomatic: He was always borrowing wine from Granny Wang and Old Wu. Sometimes he drank himself into a stupor and collapsed. Granny Wang and Old Wu noticed that strange apparitions often hovered above him.

sentences.zh: 高祖每酤留飲，酒讎數倍。

translations.literal: Gaozu each time bought wine and stayed to drink, the wine bill was several times over.
translations.idiomatic: Whenever Gaozu bought wine, he would stay and drink, running up bills several times the amount.

sentences.zh: 及見怪，歲 竟，此兩家常折券棄責。

translations.literal: When they saw the strange apparitions, at year's end, these two families constantly tore up the debt contracts and abandoned the debts.
translations.idiomatic: Whenever they saw these strange apparitions, at year's end these two families would tear up their IOUs and forgive his debts.

translations.literal: Emperor Gaozu had a prominent nose, a dragon-like countenance, magnificent beard and whiskers, and seventy-two black moles on his left thigh. He was benevolent and loved people, enjoying giving charity, and had an open-hearted disposition. He always showed great magnanimity and never concerned himself with household chores or farm work. When he came of age, he took the civil service examination and became the pavilion chief of Sishang. Among the officials in the county court, there was not one he did not treat with casual familiarity or mock. He loved wine and women. He was always borrowing wine from Granny Wang and Old Wu. Sometimes he drank himself into a stupor and collapsed. Granny Wang and Old Wu noticed that strange apparitions often hovered above him. Whenever Gaozu bought wine, he would stay and drink, running up bills several times the amount. Whenever they saw these strange apparitions, at year's end these two families would tear up their IOUs and forgive his debts.

sentences.zh: 高祖常繇咸陽，縱觀秦皇帝，喟然大息，曰：「嗟乎，大丈夫當如此矣！」

translations.literal: Gaozu often passed through Xianyang, gazed freely at the Qin emperor, sighed deeply, said: 'Alas, a great man should be like this!'
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu often passed through Xianyang and gazed upon the Qin emperor. He sighed deeply and said, 'Alas, this is how a true hero should live!'

translations.literal: Gaozu often passed through Xianyang and gazed upon the Qin emperor. He sighed deeply and said, 'Alas, this is how a true hero should live!'

sentences.zh: 單父人呂公善沛令，辟仇，從之客，因家焉。

translations.literal: Lu Gong from Shanfu was friendly with the Pei magistrate, avoided enemies, became his guest, and thus settled his family there.
translations.idiomatic: Lu Gong from Shanfu was on good terms with the magistrate of Pei. To avoid his enemies, he became the magistrate's guest and settled his family in Pei.

sentences.zh: 沛中豪傑吏聞令有重客，皆往賀。

translations.literal: The heroic officials and clerks in Pei heard that the magistrate had an important guest, all went to congratulate him.
translations.idiomatic: When the local notables and officials in Pei heard that the magistrate had an important guest, they all came to offer congratulations.

sentences.zh: 蕭何為主吏，主進，令諸 大夫曰：「進不滿千錢，坐之堂下。」

translations.literal: Xiao He was the chief clerk, in charge of receiving guests, ordered the various gentlemen saying: 'Those who present less than a thousand cash, seat them below the hall.'
translations.idiomatic: Xiao He, the chief clerk overseeing the reception, instructed the guests: 'Anyone who brings less than a thousand cash in congratulations should be seated below in the courtyard.'

sentences.zh: 高祖為亭長，素易諸吏，乃紿為謁曰「賀錢萬」，實不持一錢。

translations.literal: Gaozu was a pavilion chief, usually treated the officials casually, then lied in his calling card saying 'congratulatory money ten thousand', actually did not bring a single cash.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu, being a mere pavilion chief, was accustomed to treating officials casually. He forged a calling card claiming 'ten thousand cash in congratulations,' but brought nothing at all.

sentences.zh: 謁入，呂公大驚，起，迎之門。

translations.literal: The calling card entered, Lu Gong greatly astonished, rose, welcomed him at the gate.
translations.idiomatic: When the calling card was presented, Lu Gong was astonished. He rose and went out to welcome him at the gate.

sentences.zh: 呂公者，好相人，見高祖狀 貌，因重敬之，引入坐上坐。

translations.literal: Lu Gong was fond of physiognomy, saw Gaozu's appearance, thus greatly respected him, led him in and seated him in the seat of honor.
translations.idiomatic: Lu Gong was an expert in reading faces. When he saw Gaozu's features, he was filled with respect and seated him in the place of honor.

sentences.zh: 蕭何曰：「劉季固多大言，少成事。」

translations.literal: Xiao He said: 'Liu Ji indeed makes many great boasts, accomplishes few things.'
translations.idiomatic: Xiao He said, 'Liu Ji talks big but gets little done.'

sentences.zh: 高祖因狎侮諸客，遂坐上坐，無所詘。

translations.literal: Gaozu thus familiarly mocked the various guests, then sat in the seat of honor, without yielding.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu casually mocked the other guests and took the seat of honor without any deference.

sentences.zh: 酒闌，呂公因目固留高祖。

translations.literal: The wine feast ended, Lu Gong thus gave meaningful looks and firmly detained Gaozu.
translations.idiomatic: As the banquet wound down, Lu Gong gave meaningful glances and insisted on keeping Gaozu behind.

sentences.zh: 竟酒，後。

translations.literal: The wine feast ended, afterward.
translations.idiomatic: After the banquet concluded.

sentences.zh: 呂公曰：「臣少好 相人，相人多矣，無如季相，願季自愛。

translations.literal: Lu Gong said: 'I from youth liked physiognomy, have read many people's faces, none like Ji's features, wish Ji to take care of himself.'
translations.idiomatic: Lu Gong said, 'Since youth I've loved reading faces. I've seen many people, but none with features like yours, Liu Ji. I hope you'll take good care of yourself.'

sentences.zh: 臣有息女，願為箕帚妾。」

translations.literal: 'I have a young daughter, wish to be a broom and mat servant.'
translations.idiomatic: 'I have a daughter of marriageable age whom I would like to offer as your wife.'

sentences.zh: 酒罷，呂媼怒呂公曰：「公始常欲奇此女，與貴人。

translations.literal: The wine feast ended, Lady Lu angrily said to Lu Gong: 'You originally constantly wished to make this daughter extraordinary, give to a noble person.'
translations.idiomatic: After the banquet, Lady Lu angrily confronted her husband: 'You always said this daughter was special and deserved to marry someone noble.'

sentences.zh: 沛令善公，求之不與，何自妄許與劉季？」

translations.literal: 'The Pei magistrate is friendly with you, sought her and you did not give, why arbitrarily promise to Liu Ji?'
translations.idiomatic: 'The magistrate of Pei is your good friend. He asked for her hand and you refused. Why arbitrarily promise her to Liu Ji?'

sentences.zh: 呂公曰：「此非兒女子所知。」

translations.literal: Lu Gong said: 'This is not something women and children understand.'
translations.idiomatic: Lu Gong replied, 'This is beyond the understanding of women and children.'

sentences.zh: 卒與高祖。

translations.literal: In the end gave to Gaozu.
translations.idiomatic: In the end, she was married to Emperor Gaozu.

sentences.zh: 呂公女即呂后也，生孝惠帝、魯元公主。

translations.literal: Lu Gong's daughter was Empress Lu, gave birth to Emperor Hui and Princess Lu Yuan of Lu.
translations.idiomatic: Lu Gong's daughter became Empress Lü, bearing Emperor Hui and Princess Lu Yuan.

translations.literal: Lu Gong from Shanfu was on good terms with the magistrate of Pei. To avoid his enemies, he became the magistrate's guest and settled his family in Pei. When the local notables and officials in Pei heard that the magistrate had an important guest, they all came to offer congratulations. Xiao He, the chief clerk overseeing the reception, instructed the guests: 'Anyone who brings less than a thousand cash in congratulations should be seated below in the courtyard.' Gaozu, being a mere pavilion chief, was accustomed to treating officials casually. He forged a calling card claiming 'ten thousand cash in congratulations,' but brought nothing at all. When the calling card was presented, Lu Gong was astonished. He rose and went out to welcome him at the gate. Lu Gong was an expert in reading faces. When he saw Gaozu's features, he was filled with respect and seated him in the place of honor. Xiao He said, 'Liu Ji talks big but gets little done.' Gaozu casually mocked the other guests and took the seat of honor without any deference. As the banquet wound down, Lu Gong gave meaningful glances and insisted on keeping Gaozu behind. After the banquet concluded. Lu Gong said, 'Since youth I've loved reading faces. I've seen many people, but none with features like yours, Liu Ji. I hope you'll take good care of yourself.' 'I have a daughter of marriageable age whom I would like to offer as your wife.' After the banquet, Lady Lu angrily confronted her husband: 'You always said this daughter was special and deserved to marry someone noble.' 'The magistrate of Pei is your good friend. He asked for her hand and you refused. Why arbitrarily promise her to Liu Ji?' Lu Gong replied, 'This is beyond the understanding of women and children.' In the end, she was married to Emperor Gaozu. Lu Gong's daughter became Empress Lü, bearing Emperor Hui and Princess Lu Yuan.

sentences.zh: 高祖嘗告歸之田。

translations.literal: Gaozu once took leave and returned to the fields.
translations.idiomatic: Once Gaozu took leave to return to his farm.

sentences.zh: 呂后與兩子居田中，有一老父過請飲，呂后因餔之。

translations.literal: Empress Lu and her two children lived in the countryside, there was an old father who passed by requesting drink, Empress Lu thus fed him.
translations.idiomatic: Empress Lü and her two children were living in the countryside when an old man passed by asking for something to drink. Empress Lü fed him.

sentences.zh: 老父相后曰：「夫人天下貴人 也。」

translations.literal: The old father read Empress Lu's face saying: 'Madam is a noble person of the world.'
translations.idiomatic: The old man read her face and said, 'My lady, you are destined to be the most noble woman in the realm.'

sentences.zh: 令相兩子，見孝惠帝，曰：「夫人所以貴者，乃此男也。」

translations.literal: Ordered him to read the two children's faces, when he saw Emperor Hui, said: 'The reason madam is noble is this male child.'
translations.idiomatic: He asked the old man to read the faces of her two children. When he saw Emperor Hui, he said, 'This boy is the source of your nobility, my lady.'

sentences.zh: 相魯元公主，亦皆貴。

translations.literal: Read Princess Lu Yuan's face, also all noble.
translations.idiomatic: He read Princess Lu Yuan's face as well and declared that she too would be noble.

sentences.zh: 老父已去，高祖適從旁舍來，呂后具言客有過，相我子母皆大貴。

translations.literal: The old father had left, Gaozu happened to come from the neighboring house, Empress Lu completely told him the guest who passed by, read my children and mother all greatly noble.
translations.idiomatic: After the old man left, Gaozu happened to arrive from the neighboring shed. Empress Lü told him everything about the visitor who had read their faces and predicted great nobility for her and her children.

sentences.zh: 高祖問， 曰：「未遠。」

translations.literal: Gaozu asked, said: 'Not far.'
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu asked where he had gone. 'Not far,' she replied.

sentences.zh: 乃追及，問老父。

translations.literal: Then pursued and caught up, questioned the old father.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu went after him and caught up, then questioned the old man.

sentences.zh: 老父曰：「鄉者夫人兒子皆以君，君相貴不可言。」

translations.literal: The old father said: 'Just now madam and children all take after you, your features noble beyond words.'
translations.idiomatic: The old man said, 'Just now I read the faces of your wife and children. They all resemble you, and your features indicate nobility beyond description.'

sentences.zh: 高祖乃謝曰：「誠如父言，不敢忘德。」

translations.literal: Gaozu then thanked saying: 'Truly as father says, do not dare forget the kindness.'
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu thanked him profusely: 'You speak truly, old sir. I will never forget your kindness.'

sentences.zh: 及高祖貴，遂不知老父處。

translations.literal: When Gaozu became noble, then did not know the old father's whereabouts.
translations.idiomatic: When Gaozu rose to power, he could no longer find the old man.

translations.literal: Once Gaozu took leave to return to his farm. Empress Lü and her two children were living in the countryside when an old man passed by asking for something to drink. Empress Lü fed him. The old man read her face and said, 'My lady, you are destined to be the most noble woman in the realm.' He asked the old man to read the faces of her two children. When he saw Emperor Hui, he said, 'This boy is the source of your nobility, my lady.' He read Princess Lu Yuan's face as well and declared that she too would be noble. After the old man left, Gaozu happened to arrive from the neighboring shed. Empress Lü told him everything about the visitor who had read their faces and predicted great nobility for her and her children. Gaozu asked where he had gone. 'Not far,' she replied. Gaozu went after him and caught up, then questioned the old man. The old man said, 'Just now I read the faces of your wife and children. They all resemble you, and your features indicate nobility beyond description.' Gaozu thanked him profusely: 'You speak truly, old sir. I will never forget your kindness.' When Gaozu rose to power, he could no longer find the old man.

sentences.zh: 高祖為亭長，乃鲈竹皮為冠，令求盜之薛治，時時冠之，及貴常冠，所謂「劉氏冠」也。

translations.literal: Gaozu as pavilion chief, then made a hat from sharkskin, ordered the thief-catcher from Xue to make it, wore it from time to time, and when noble constantly wore it, this is called 'Liu family hat'.
translations.idiomatic: As pavilion chief, Gaozu had a hat made from sharkskin and ordered a blacksmith from Xue to craft it. He wore it occasionally then, and continued wearing it constantly after rising to power. This became known as the 'Liu family hat.'

translations.literal: As pavilion chief, Gaozu had a hat made from sharkskin and ordered a blacksmith from Xue to craft it. He wore it occasionally then, and continued wearing it constantly after rising to power. This became known as the 'Liu family hat.'

sentences.zh: 高祖以亭長為縣送徒驪山，徒多道亡。

translations.literal: Gaozu as pavilion chief was ordered by the county to escort convicts to Mount Li, the convicts many fled on the road.
translations.idiomatic: As pavilion chief, Gaozu was assigned by the county to escort convicts to Mount Li. Many of the convicts escaped along the way.

sentences.zh: 自度比至皆亡之，到豐西澤中亭，止飲，夜皆解縱所送徒。

translations.literal: He estimated that by the time he arrived all would have fled, arrived at the pavilion in the western marshes of Feng, stopped to drink, at night all released the convicts he was escorting.
translations.idiomatic: He figured that by the time they reached Mount Li, all the convicts would have escaped. He stopped at a pavilion in Feng's western marshes for a drink, then released all the convicts under his charge that night.

translations.literal: Said: '
translations.idiomatic: He said, '

translations.literal: As pavilion chief, Gaozu was assigned by the county to escort convicts to Mount Li. Many of the convicts escaped along the way. He figured that by the time they reached Mount Li, all the convicts would have escaped. He stopped at a pavilion in Feng's western marshes for a drink, then released all the convicts under his charge that night. He said, '

sentences.zh: 公等皆去，吾亦從此逝矣！」

translations.literal: You gentlemen all go, I also from here depart!'
translations.idiomatic: 'You may all go now. I too shall depart from here!'

sentences.zh: 徒中壯士願從諸十餘人。

translations.literal: Among the convicts the strong men who wished to follow were more than ten people.
translations.idiomatic: Among the convicts, more than ten strong men chose to follow him.

sentences.zh: 高祖被酒，夜徑澤中，令一人行前。

translations.literal: Gaozu was drunk, at night went straight through the marshes, ordered one person to go ahead.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu, having drunk too much, traveled straight through the marshes at night and sent one man ahead to scout.

sentences.zh: 行前者還報曰：「

translations.literal: The one who went ahead returned and reported saying: '
translations.idiomatic: The scout returned and reported, '

translations.literal: 'You may all go now. I too shall depart from here!' Among the convicts, more than ten strong men chose to follow him. Gaozu, having drunk too much, traveled straight through the marshes at night and sent one man ahead to scout. The scout returned and reported, '

sentences.zh: 前有大蛇當徑，願還。」

translations.literal: Ahead there is a large snake blocking the path, wish to turn back.'
translations.idiomatic: 'There's a huge snake blocking the path ahead. We should turn back.'

sentences.zh: 高祖醉，曰：「壯士行，何畏！」

translations.literal: Gaozu was drunk, said: 'A brave man walks forward, what is there to fear!'
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu, though drunk, declared, 'A real man presses forward—what's there to fear!'

sentences.zh: 乃前，拔劍斬蛇。

translations.literal: Then went forward, drew sword and cut the snake.
translations.idiomatic: He pressed forward, drew his sword, and slashed at the snake.

sentences.zh: 蛇分為兩，道開。

translations.literal: The snake divided into two, the path opened.
translations.idiomatic: The snake split in two, clearing the path.

sentences.zh: 行數里， 醉困臥。

translations.literal: Walked several li, drunk and weary lay down.
translations.idiomatic: He walked a few li further, then collapsed in drunken exhaustion.

sentences.zh: 後人來至蛇所，有一老嫗夜哭。

translations.literal: Later people came to the snake's location, there was an old woman crying at night.
translations.idiomatic: Later, people came to the spot where the snake had been and found an old woman weeping there at night.

sentences.zh: 人問嫗何哭，嫗曰：「人殺吾子。」

translations.literal: People asked the old woman why she cried, the old woman said: 'A person killed my son.'
translations.idiomatic: They asked the old woman why she was crying. 'Someone killed my son,' she replied.

sentences.zh: 人曰：「嫗子何為見殺？」

translations.literal: People said: 'Old woman's son why was he killed?'
translations.idiomatic: They asked, 'How did your son come to be killed?'

sentences.zh: 嫗曰：「吾子，白帝子也，化為蛇，當道，今者赤帝子斬 之，故哭。」

translations.literal: Old woman said: 'My son was the son of the White Emperor, transformed into a snake, blocked the path, now the son of the Red Emperor cut him, therefore cry.'
translations.idiomatic: The old woman replied, 'My son was the son of the White Emperor. He transformed into a snake to block the path, but now the son of the Red Emperor has slain him. That is why I weep.'

sentences.zh: 人乃以嫗為不誠，欲苦之，嫗因忽不見。

translations.literal: People then considered the old woman not sincere, wished to harm her, the old woman thus suddenly disappeared.
translations.idiomatic: The people thought she was lying and wanted to beat her, but she suddenly vanished.

sentences.zh: 後人至，高祖覺。

translations.literal: Later people arrived, Gaozu awoke.
translations.idiomatic: When the others arrived, Gaozu awoke.

sentences.zh: 告高祖，高祖乃心獨喜，自負。

translations.literal: Told Gaozu, Gaozu then in his heart alone rejoiced, considered himself superior.
translations.idiomatic: They told Gaozu what happened. He was secretly thrilled and began to think highly of himself.

sentences.zh: 諸從者日益畏之。

translations.literal: The various followers increasingly feared him.
translations.idiomatic: His followers grew increasingly awed by him.

translations.literal: 'There's a huge snake blocking the path ahead. We should turn back.' Gaozu, though drunk, declared, 'A real man presses forward—what's there to fear!' He pressed forward, drew his sword, and slashed at the snake. The snake split in two, clearing the path. He walked a few li further, then collapsed in drunken exhaustion. Later, people came to the spot where the snake had been and found an old woman weeping there at night. They asked the old woman why she was crying. 'Someone killed my son,' she replied. They asked, 'How did your son come to be killed?' The old woman replied, 'My son was the son of the White Emperor. He transformed into a snake to block the path, but now the son of the Red Emperor has slain him. That is why I weep.' The people thought she was lying and wanted to beat her, but she suddenly vanished. When the others arrived, Gaozu awoke. They told Gaozu what happened. He was secretly thrilled and began to think highly of himself. His followers grew increasingly awed by him.

sentences.zh: 秦始皇帝嘗曰「東南有天子氣」，於是東游以猒當之。

translations.literal: Qin Shi Huang often said 'there is emperor aura in the southeast', therefore traveled east to suppress it.
translations.idiomatic: Qin Shi Huang had often said, 'There is imperial aura in the southeast.' Therefore he traveled east to suppress it.

sentences.zh: 高祖隱於芒、碭山澤間，呂后與人俱求，常得之。

translations.literal: Gaozu hid in the mountains and marshes between Mang and Dang, Empress Lu and others together sought him, constantly found him.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu hid himself in the hills and marshes between Mang and Dang. Empress Lü and others searched for him together and always managed to find him.

sentences.zh: 高祖怪問之。

translations.literal: Gaozu strangely questioned her.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu asked her curiously.

sentences.zh: 呂后曰：「季所居上常有雲氣，故從往常得季。」

translations.literal: Empress Lu said: 'Where Ji resides above constantly has cloud aura, therefore following it constantly finds Ji.'
translations.idiomatic: Empress Lü replied, 'Wherever you hide, Liu Ji, there's always a cloud of auspicious vapor above you. That's how we always find you.'

sentences.zh: 高祖又喜。

translations.literal: Gaozu again was happy.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu was pleased once more.

sentences.zh: 沛中子弟或聞之，多欲附者矣。

translations.literal: Some of the youths in Pei heard of it, many wished to attach themselves.
translations.idiomatic: Some of the young men in Pei heard about this and many wanted to join him.

translations.literal: Qin Shi Huang had often said, 'There is imperial aura in the southeast.' Therefore he traveled east to suppress it. Gaozu hid himself in the hills and marshes between Mang and Dang. Empress Lü and others searched for him together and always managed to find him. Gaozu asked her curiously. Empress Lü replied, 'Wherever you hide, Liu Ji, there's always a cloud of auspicious vapor above you. That's how we always find you.' Gaozu was pleased once more. Some of the young men in Pei heard about this and many wanted to join him.

sentences.zh: 於是樊噲從高祖來。

translations.literal: Therefore Fan Kuai followed Gaozu and came.
translations.idiomatic: Thus Fan Kuai came to join Gaozu.

sentences.zh: 沛令後悔，恐其有變，乃閉城城守，欲誅蕭、曹。

translations.literal: The Pei magistrate afterward regretted, feared there would be change, then closed the city gates and defended, wished to execute Xiao and Cao.
translations.idiomatic: The magistrate of Pei later regretted his decision. Fearing trouble, he closed the city gates and prepared to defend against attack. He wanted to execute Xiao He and Cao Can.

sentences.zh: 蕭、曹恐，踰城保高祖。

translations.literal: Xiao and Cao feared, climbed over the wall to protect Gaozu.
translations.idiomatic: Xiao He and Cao Can, fearing for their lives, climbed over the wall to join Gaozu.

sentences.zh: 高祖乃書 帛射城上，與沛父老曰：「天下同苦秦久矣。

translations.literal: Gaozu then wrote on silk and shot it onto the city wall, telling the Pei elders: 'The world together has suffered under Qin for a long time.'
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu wrote a message on silk and shot it over the city wall to the elders of Pei: 'All under heaven have suffered long under Qin oppression.'

sentences.zh: 今父老雖為沛令守，諸侯並起，今屠沛。

translations.literal: Now although elders defend for the Pei magistrate, the feudal lords all rise, now will slaughter Pei.
translations.idiomatic: 'Though you elders defend the magistrate of Pei, the feudal lords are rising up everywhere. They will soon slaughter the people of Pei.'

sentences.zh: 沛今共誅令，擇可立立之，以應諸侯，即室家完。

translations.literal: Pei now together execute the magistrate, choose suitable one and establish him, to respond to the feudal lords, then families complete.
translations.idiomatic: 'If Pei executes the magistrate together and chooses a suitable leader to join the other feudal lords, your families will be safe.'

sentences.zh: 不然，父子俱屠，無為 也。」

translations.literal: If not, fathers and sons together slaughtered, useless.'
translations.idiomatic: 'Otherwise, fathers and sons will all be slaughtered—it will be pointless.'

sentences.zh: 父老乃帥子弟共殺沛令，開城門迎高祖，欲以為沛令。

translations.literal: The elders then led the young men together to kill the Pei magistrate, opened the city gates to welcome Gaozu, wished to make him Pei magistrate.
translations.idiomatic: The elders led the young men to kill the magistrate and opened the city gates to welcome Gaozu. They wanted to make him the new magistrate of Pei.

sentences.zh: 高祖曰：「天下方擾，諸侯並起，令置將不善，一敗塗地。

translations.literal: Gaozu said: 'The world is currently in chaos, feudal lords all rise, if the magistrate appoints generals poorly, one defeat and all lost.'
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu replied, 'The realm is in turmoil with feudal lords rising everywhere. If the magistrate chooses poor generals, one defeat will destroy everything.'

sentences.zh: 吾非敢自愛，恐能薄，不能完父兄子弟。

translations.literal: I do not dare cherish myself, fear my abilities are meager, cannot protect fathers, elder brothers, younger brothers.
translations.idiomatic: 'I'm not trying to protect myself. I fear my abilities are insufficient to protect our fathers, brothers, and families.'

sentences.zh: 此 大事，願吏擇可者。」

translations.literal: This is a great matter, wish officials choose suitable one.'
translations.idiomatic: 'This is a grave responsibility. I hope the officials will choose someone suitable.'

sentences.zh: 蕭、曹等皆文吏，自愛，恐事不就，後秦種族其家，盡讓高祖。

translations.literal: Xiao, Cao and others all were civil officials, cherished themselves, feared the matter would not succeed, afterward Qin would exterminate their families, all yielded to Gaozu.
translations.idiomatic: Xiao He, Cao Can, and the other civil officials, concerned for their own safety and fearing failure would lead to Qin exterminating their families, all deferred to Gaozu.

sentences.zh: 諸父老皆曰：「平生所聞劉季奇怪，當貴，且卜筮之，莫如劉季最吉。」

translations.literal: All the elders said: 'In our lives we have heard Liu Ji is strange and extraordinary, should be noble, moreover divining it, none is more auspicious than Liu Ji.'
translations.idiomatic: The elders all said, 'Throughout our lives we've heard that Liu Ji is extraordinary. He is destined for nobility. And when we consulted the divination, none showed more auspicious signs than Liu Ji.'

sentences.zh: 高祖 數讓。

translations.literal: Gaozu repeatedly declined.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu repeatedly declined the position.

sentences.zh: 眾莫肯為，高祖乃立為沛公。

translations.literal: The crowd none would do it, Gaozu then was established as Pei Gong.
translations.idiomatic: No one else would accept it, so Gaozu was established as Lord of Pei.

sentences.zh: 祠黃帝，祭蚩尤於沛廷，而釁鼓旗。

translations.literal: Sacrificed to the Yellow Emperor, offered sacrifice to Chi You in the Pei court, and smeared blood on drums and flags.
translations.idiomatic: He sacrificed to the Yellow Emperor and offered rites to Chi You in the Pei court, smearing the drums and banners with blood.

sentences.zh: 幟皆赤，由所殺蛇白帝子，所殺者赤帝子故也。

translations.literal: The banners all red, because the killed snake was White Emperor's son, the one who killed was Red Emperor's son therefore.
translations.idiomatic: All banners were red, because the snake he killed was the son of the White Emperor, and he who killed it was the son of the Red Emperor.

sentences.zh: 於是少年豪吏如蕭、曹、樊噲等皆為收沛子 弟，得三千人。

translations.literal: Therefore young heroic officials like Xiao, Cao, Fan Kuai and others all recruited Pei youths, got three thousand.
translations.idiomatic: The young leaders like Xiao He, Cao Can, Fan Kuai, and others recruited the young men of Pei and gathered three thousand troops.

translations.literal: Thus Fan Kuai came to join Gaozu. The magistrate of Pei later regretted his decision. Fearing trouble, he closed the city gates and prepared to defend against attack. He wanted to execute Xiao He and Cao Can. Xiao He and Cao Can, fearing for their lives, climbed over the wall to join Gaozu. Gaozu wrote a message on silk and shot it over the city wall to the elders of Pei: 'All under heaven have suffered long under Qin oppression.' 'Though you elders defend the magistrate of Pei, the feudal lords are rising up everywhere. They will soon slaughter the people of Pei.' 'If Pei executes the magistrate together and chooses a suitable leader to join the other feudal lords, your families will be safe.' 'Otherwise, fathers and sons will all be slaughtered—it will be pointless.' The elders led the young men to kill the magistrate and opened the city gates to welcome Gaozu. They wanted to make him the new magistrate of Pei. Gaozu replied, 'The realm is in turmoil with feudal lords rising everywhere. If the magistrate chooses poor generals, one defeat will destroy everything.' 'I'm not trying to protect myself. I fear my abilities are insufficient to protect our fathers, brothers, and families.' 'This is a grave responsibility. I hope the officials will choose someone suitable.' Xiao He, Cao Can, and the other civil officials, concerned for their own safety and fearing failure would lead to Qin exterminating their families, all deferred to Gaozu. The elders all said, 'Throughout our lives we've heard that Liu Ji is extraordinary. He is destined for nobility. And when we consulted the divination, none showed more auspicious signs than Liu Ji.' Gaozu repeatedly declined the position. No one else would accept it, so Gaozu was established as Lord of Pei. He sacrificed to the Yellow Emperor and offered rites to Chi You in the Pei court, smearing the drums and banners with blood. All banners were red, because the snake he killed was the son of the White Emperor, and he who killed it was the son of the Red Emperor. The young leaders like Xiao He, Cao Can, Fan Kuai, and others recruited the young men of Pei and gathered three thousand troops.

sentences.zh: 是月，項梁與兄子羽起吳。

translations.literal: This month, Xiang Liang and his brother's son Yu rose in Wu.
translations.idiomatic: That month, Xiang Liang and his nephew Xiang Yu rose up in Wu.

sentences.zh: 田儋與從弟榮、橫起齊，自立為齊王。

translations.literal: Tian Dan and his younger cousins Rong, Heng rose in Qi, self-established as Qi King.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Dan and his cousins Tian Rong and Tian Heng rose up in Qi and proclaimed themselves King of Qi.

sentences.zh: 韓廣自立為燕王。

translations.literal: Han Guang self-established as Yan King.
translations.idiomatic: Han Guang proclaimed himself King of Yan.

sentences.zh: 魏咎自立為魏王。

translations.literal: Wei Jiu self-established as Wei King.
translations.idiomatic: Wei Jiu proclaimed himself King of Wei.

sentences.zh: 陳涉之將周章西入關，至戲，秦將章邯距破之。

translations.literal: Chen Sheng's general Zhou Zhang entered the pass westward, arrived at Xi, Qin general Zhang Han resisted and defeated him.
translations.idiomatic: Chen Sheng's general Zhou Zhang marched west through the pass and reached Xi, where Qin general Zhang Han met and defeated him.

translations.literal: That month, Xiang Liang and his nephew Xiang Yu rose up in Wu. Tian Dan and his cousins Tian Rong and Tian Heng rose up in Qi and proclaimed themselves King of Qi. Han Guang proclaimed himself King of Yan. Wei Jiu proclaimed himself King of Wei. Chen Sheng's general Zhou Zhang marched west through the pass and reached Xi, where Qin general Zhang Han met and defeated him.

sentences.zh: 秦二年十月，沛公攻胡陵、方與，還守豐。

translations.literal: Qin second year tenth month, Pei Gong attacked Hu Ling and Fang Yu, returned to defend Feng.
translations.idiomatic: In the tenth month of the second year of Qin, Lord Pei attacked Hu Ling and Fang Yu, then returned to defend Feng.

sentences.zh: 秦泗川監平將兵圍豐。

translations.literal: Qin Sishui inspector Ping led troops to surround Feng.
translations.idiomatic: Qin inspector Ping of Sishui commandery led troops to besiege Feng.

sentences.zh: 二日，出與戰，破之。

translations.literal: Two days, went out and fought with them, defeated them.
translations.idiomatic: Two days later, Lord Pei sallied forth to fight and defeated them.

sentences.zh: 令雍齒守豐。

translations.literal: Ordered Yong Chi to defend Feng.
translations.idiomatic: He ordered Yong Chi to defend Feng.

sentences.zh: 十 一月，沛公引兵之薜。

translations.literal: Eleventh month, Pei Gong led troops to Xi.
translations.idiomatic: In the eleventh month, Lord Pei led his troops to Xi.

sentences.zh: 秦泗川守壯兵敗於薛，走至戚，沛公左司馬得殺之。

translations.literal: Qin Sishui defender Zhuang's troops defeated at Xue, fled to Qi, Pei Gong's left marshal captured and killed him.
translations.idiomatic: The Qin defender Zhuang's troops were defeated at Xue and fled to Qi, where Lord Pei's left marshal captured and executed him.

sentences.zh: 沛公還軍亢父，至方與。

translations.literal: Pei Gong returned his army to Kang Fu, arrived at Fang Yu.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pei withdrew his army to Kang Fu and arrived at Fang Yu.

sentences.zh: 趙王武臣為其將所殺。

translations.literal: Zhao King Wu Chen was killed by his general.
translations.idiomatic: King Wu Chen of Zhao was assassinated by one of his generals.

sentences.zh: 十二月，楚王陳涉為其御莊賈所殺。

translations.literal: Twelfth month, Chu King Chen Sheng was killed by his charioteer Zhuang Jia.
translations.idiomatic: In the twelfth month, King Chen Sheng of Chu was assassinated by his charioteer Zhuang Jia.

sentences.zh: 魏人 周市略地豐沛，使人謂雍齒曰：「豐，故梁徙也，今魏地已定者數十城。

translations.literal: Wei person Zhou Shi conquered territory Feng Pei, sent person to tell Yong Chi: 'Feng was originally Liang migrants, now Wei territory already settled dozens of cities.'
translations.idiomatic: Zhou Shi of Wei, having conquered the Feng and Pei regions, sent a messenger to Yong Chi saying, 'Feng was originally settled by migrants from Liang. Wei has now secured dozens of cities.'

sentences.zh: 齒今下魏，魏以齒為侯守豐；

translations.literal: 'Chi now submit to Wei, Wei will make Chi marquis to guard Feng;'
translations.idiomatic: 'If Yong Chi submits to Wei now, Wei will make him a marquis and let him defend Feng;'

sentences.zh: 不下，且屠豐。」

translations.literal: 'if not submit, then will slaughter Feng.'
translations.idiomatic: 'if you don't submit, we'll slaughter the people of Feng.'

sentences.zh: 雍齒雅不欲屬沛公，及魏招之，即反為魏守 豐。

translations.literal: Yong Chi usually did not wish to belong to Pei Gong, when Wei summoned him, immediately rebelled to guard Feng for Wei.
translations.idiomatic: Yong Chi had never wanted to serve Lord Pei. When Wei summoned him, he immediately defected and began defending Feng for Wei.

sentences.zh: 沛公攻豐，不能取。

translations.literal: Pei Gong attacked Feng, could not capture it.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pei attacked Feng but could not take it.

sentences.zh: 沛公還之沛，怨雍齒與豐子弟畔之。

translations.literal: Pei Gong returned to Pei, resented Yong Chi and the Feng youths rebelling against him.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pei returned to Pei, resentful that Yong Chi and the young men of Feng had rebelled against him.

translations.literal: In the tenth month of the second year of Qin, Lord Pei attacked Hu Ling and Fang Yu, then returned to defend Feng. Qin inspector Ping of Sishui commandery led troops to besiege Feng. Two days later, Lord Pei sallied forth to fight and defeated them. He ordered Yong Chi to defend Feng. In the eleventh month, Lord Pei led his troops to Xi. The Qin defender Zhuang's troops were defeated at Xue and fled to Qi, where Lord Pei's left marshal captured and executed him. Lord Pei withdrew his army to Kang Fu and arrived at Fang Yu. King Wu Chen of Zhao was assassinated by one of his generals. In the twelfth month, King Chen Sheng of Chu was assassinated by his charioteer Zhuang Jia. Zhou Shi of Wei, having conquered the Feng and Pei regions, sent a messenger to Yong Chi saying, 'Feng was originally settled by migrants from Liang. Wei has now secured dozens of cities.' 'If Yong Chi submits to Wei now, Wei will make him a marquis and let him defend Feng;' 'if you don't submit, we'll slaughter the people of Feng.' Yong Chi had never wanted to serve Lord Pei. When Wei summoned him, he immediately defected and began defending Feng for Wei. Lord Pei attacked Feng but could not take it. Lord Pei returned to Pei, resentful that Yong Chi and the young men of Feng had rebelled against him.

sentences.zh: 正月，張耳等立趙後趙歇為趙王。

translations.literal: First month, Zhang Er and others established Zhao descendant Zhao Xie as Zhao King.
translations.idiomatic: In the first month, Zhang Er and others installed Zhao Xie, a descendant of the Zhao royal family, as King of Zhao.

sentences.zh: 東陽甯君、秦嘉立景駒為楚王，在留。

translations.literal: Dongyang Ning Jun, Qin Jia established Jing Ju as Chu King, at Liu.
translations.idiomatic: Ning Jun of Dongyang and Qin Jia installed Jing Ju as King of Chu, with his capital at Liu.

sentences.zh: 沛公往從之，道得張良，遂與俱 見景駒，請兵以攻豐。

translations.literal: Pei Gong went to follow them, on the road obtained Zhang Liang, then together went to see Jing Ju, requested troops to attack Feng.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pei went to join them. Along the way he met Zhang Liang, and together they went to see King Jing Ju to request troops for attacking Feng.

sentences.zh: 時章邯從陳，別將司馬镛將兵北定楚地，屠相，至碭。

translations.literal: At this time Zhang Han came from Chen, separate general Sima Ni led troops north to pacify Chu territory, massacred Xiang, arrived at Dang.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Zhang Han was advancing from Chen. His deputy general Sima Ni led troops north to pacify Chu territory, massacring the people of Xiang and reaching Dang.

sentences.zh: 東陽甯君、沛公引兵西，與戰蕭西，不利，還收兵聚留。

translations.literal: Dongyang Ning Jun, Pei Gong led troops west, fought battle at Xiao west, unfavorable, returned gathered troops at Liu.
translations.idiomatic: Ning Jun of Dongyang and Lord Pei led troops west and fought a battle west of Xiao, but were defeated. They retreated and regrouped at Liu.

sentences.zh: 二月，攻碭，三日拔之。

translations.literal: Second month, attacked Dang, three days captured it.
translations.idiomatic: In the second month, they attacked Dang and captured it after three days.

sentences.zh: 收碭 兵，得六千人，與故合九千人。

translations.literal: Recruited Dang troops, got six thousand, combined with original made nine thousand.
translations.idiomatic: They recruited troops from Dang, gaining six thousand men, bringing their total to nine thousand.

sentences.zh: 三月，攻下邑，拔之。

translations.literal: Third month, attacked Xiayi, captured it.
translations.idiomatic: In the third month, they attacked Xiayi and captured it.

sentences.zh: 還擊豐，不下。

translations.literal: Returned to attack Feng, could not capture.
translations.idiomatic: They returned to attack Feng but could not take it.

sentences.zh: 四月，項梁擊殺景駒、秦嘉，止薛，沛公往見之。

translations.literal: Fourth month, Xiang Liang attacked and killed Jing Ju, Qin Jia, stopped at Xue, Pei Gong went to see him.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourth month, Xiang Liang attacked and killed Jing Ju and Qin Jia. He halted at Xue, and Lord Pei went to meet him.

sentences.zh: 項梁益沛公卒五千人，五大夫將十人。

translations.literal: Xiang Liang increased Pei Gong's troops five thousand, Grand Master generals ten people.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Liang gave Lord Pei five thousand additional troops and ten generals of the rank of Grand Master.

sentences.zh: 沛公 還，引兵攻豐，拔之。

translations.literal: Pei Gong returned, led troops to attack Feng, captured it.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pei returned, led his troops to attack Feng, and captured it.

sentences.zh: 雍齒奔魏。

translations.literal: Yong Chi fled to Wei.
translations.idiomatic: Yong Chi fled to Wei.

translations.literal: In the first month, Zhang Er and others installed Zhao Xie, a descendant of the Zhao royal family, as King of Zhao. Ning Jun of Dongyang and Qin Jia installed Jing Ju as King of Chu, with his capital at Liu. Lord Pei went to join them. Along the way he met Zhang Liang, and together they went to see King Jing Ju to request troops for attacking Feng. At this time, Zhang Han was advancing from Chen. His deputy general Sima Ni led troops north to pacify Chu territory, massacring the people of Xiang and reaching Dang. Ning Jun of Dongyang and Lord Pei led troops west and fought a battle west of Xiao, but were defeated. They retreated and regrouped at Liu. In the second month, they attacked Dang and captured it after three days. They recruited troops from Dang, gaining six thousand men, bringing their total to nine thousand. In the third month, they attacked Xiayi and captured it. They returned to attack Feng but could not take it. In the fourth month, Xiang Liang attacked and killed Jing Ju and Qin Jia. He halted at Xue, and Lord Pei went to meet him. Xiang Liang gave Lord Pei five thousand additional troops and ten generals of the rank of Grand Master. Lord Pei returned, led his troops to attack Feng, and captured it. Yong Chi fled to Wei.

sentences.zh: 五月，項羽拔襄城還。

translations.literal: Fifth month, Xiang Yu captured Xiangcheng and returned.
translations.idiomatic: In the fifth month, Xiang Yu captured Xiangcheng and returned.

sentences.zh: 項梁盡召別將。

translations.literal: Xiang Liang completely summoned the separate generals.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Liang summoned all his deputy generals.

sentences.zh: 六月，沛公如薛，與項梁共立楚懷王孫心為楚懷王。

translations.literal: Sixth month, Pei Gong went to Xue, together with Xiang Liang established Chu King Huai's grandson Xin as Chu King Huai.
translations.idiomatic: In the sixth month, Lord Pei went to Xue and together with Xiang Liang installed Xin, grandson of King Huai of Chu, as King Huai of Chu.

sentences.zh: 章邯破殺魏王 咎、齊王田儋於臨濟。

translations.literal: Zhang Han defeated and killed Wei King Jiu, Qi King Tian Dan at Linji.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Han defeated and killed King Jiu of Wei and King Tian Dan of Qi at Linji.

sentences.zh: 七月，大霖雨。

translations.literal: Seventh month, great continuous rain.
translations.idiomatic: In the seventh month, there was continuous heavy rain.

sentences.zh: 沛公攻亢父。

translations.literal: Pei Gong attacked Kang Fu.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pei attacked Kang Fu.

sentences.zh: 章邯圍田榮於東阿。

translations.literal: Zhang Han besieged Tian Rong at Dong'a.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Han besieged Tian Rong at Dong'a.

sentences.zh: 沛公與項梁共救田榮，大破章邯東阿。

translations.literal: Pei Gong together with Xiang Liang rescued Tian Rong, greatly defeated Zhang Han at Dong'a.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pei and Xiang Liang together went to rescue Tian Rong and inflicted a major defeat on Zhang Han at Dong'a.

sentences.zh: 田榮歸，沛公、項羽追北，至城陽，攻屠其城。

translations.literal: Tian Rong returned, Pei Gong, Xiang Yu pursued north, arrived at Chengyang, attacked and slaughtered its city.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Rong returned home. Lord Pei and Xiang Yu pursued the retreating enemy northward, reaching Chengyang where they attacked and massacred the inhabitants.

sentences.zh: 軍濮 陽東，復與章邯戰，又破之。

translations.literal: Camped east of Puyang, again fought with Zhang Han, again defeated him.
translations.idiomatic: They camped east of Puyang and fought Zhang Han again, defeating him once more.

translations.literal: In the fifth month, Xiang Yu captured Xiangcheng and returned. Xiang Liang summoned all his deputy generals. In the sixth month, Lord Pei went to Xue and together with Xiang Liang installed Xin, grandson of King Huai of Chu, as King Huai of Chu. Zhang Han defeated and killed King Jiu of Wei and King Tian Dan of Qi at Linji. In the seventh month, there was continuous heavy rain. Lord Pei attacked Kang Fu. Zhang Han besieged Tian Rong at Dong'a. Lord Pei and Xiang Liang together went to rescue Tian Rong and inflicted a major defeat on Zhang Han at Dong'a. Tian Rong returned home. Lord Pei and Xiang Yu pursued the retreating enemy northward, reaching Chengyang where they attacked and massacred the inhabitants. They camped east of Puyang and fought Zhang Han again, defeating him once more.

sentences.zh: 章邯復振，守濮陽，環水。

translations.literal: Zhang Han again recovered, defended Puyang, surrounded by water.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Han rallied again and defended Puyang, which was surrounded by water.

sentences.zh: 沛公、項羽去攻定陶。

translations.literal: Pei Gong, Xiang Yu left to attack Dingtao.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pei and Xiang Yu departed to attack Dingtao.

sentences.zh: 八月，田榮立田儋子市為齊王。

translations.literal: Eighth month, Tian Rong established Tian Dan's son Shi as Qi King.
translations.idiomatic: In the eighth month, Tian Rong installed Tian Shi, son of Tian Dan, as King of Qi.

sentences.zh: 定陶未下，沛公與項羽西略地至雍丘，與秦軍戰，大敗之，斬三川守李由。

translations.literal: Dingtao not yet fallen, Pei Gong together with Xiang Yu west conquered territory to Yongqiu, fought with Qin army, greatly defeated them, beheaded Sanchuan defender Li You.
translations.idiomatic: While Dingtao still held out, Lord Pei and Xiang Yu marched west conquering territory until they reached Yongqiu. There they fought the Qin army, inflicted a major defeat, and beheaded Li You, defender of Sanchuan commandery.

sentences.zh: 還攻外黃，外黃未下。

translations.literal: Returned to attack Waihuang, Waihuang did not fall.
translations.idiomatic: They returned to attack Waihuang, but could not capture it.

translations.literal: Zhang Han rallied again and defended Puyang, which was surrounded by water. Lord Pei and Xiang Yu departed to attack Dingtao. In the eighth month, Tian Rong installed Tian Shi, son of Tian Dan, as King of Qi. While Dingtao still held out, Lord Pei and Xiang Yu marched west conquering territory until they reached Yongqiu. There they fought the Qin army, inflicted a major defeat, and beheaded Li You, defender of Sanchuan commandery. They returned to attack Waihuang, but could not capture it.

sentences.zh: 項梁再破秦軍，有驕色。

translations.literal: Xiang Liang again defeated Qin army, had arrogant appearance.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Liang defeated the Qin army again and grew arrogant.

sentences.zh: 宋義諫，不聽。

translations.literal: Song Yi advised, did not listen.
translations.idiomatic: Song Yi advised him against it, but he would not listen.

sentences.zh: 秦益章邯兵。

translations.literal: Qin increased Zhang Han's troops.
translations.idiomatic: Qin reinforced Zhang Han with additional troops.

sentences.zh: 九月，章邯夜銜枚擊項梁定陶，大破之，殺項梁。

translations.literal: Ninth month, Zhang Han night held wooden gag attacked Xiang Liang at Dingtao, greatly defeated him, killed Xiang Liang.
translations.idiomatic: In the ninth month, Zhang Han attacked Xiang Liang at Dingtao under cover of night with gags in mouths to maintain silence. He inflicted a major defeat and killed Xiang Liang.

sentences.zh: 時連雨自七月至九月。

translations.literal: At this time continuous rain from seventh month to ninth month.
translations.idiomatic: Continuous rain fell from the seventh through ninth months.

sentences.zh: 沛公、項羽方攻陳留，聞梁死，士卒恐，乃與將軍呂臣引兵而東，徙懷王自盱台都彭城。

translations.literal: Pei Gong, Xiang Yu just attacking Chenliu, heard Liang died, soldiers afraid, then together with general Lu Chen led troops east, moved King Huai from Xutai capital to Pengcheng.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pei and Xiang Yu were in the midst of attacking Chenliu when they heard of Xiang Liang's death. Their troops were terrified, so they joined with General Lu Chen and led their forces east, moving King Huai from Xutai to establish his capital at Pengcheng.

sentences.zh: 呂臣軍彭城東，項羽軍彭城西，沛公軍碭。

translations.literal: Lu Chen's army east of Pengcheng, Xiang Yu's army west of Pengcheng, Pei Gong's army at Dang.
translations.idiomatic: Lu Chen's army camped east of Pengcheng, Xiang Yu's army west of Pengcheng, and Lord Pei's army at Dang.

sentences.zh: 魏咎弟豹 自立為魏王。

translations.literal: Wei Jiu's younger brother Bao self-established as Wei King.
translations.idiomatic: Wei Jiu's younger brother Bao proclaimed himself King of Wei.

sentences.zh: 後九月，懷王并呂臣、項羽軍自將之。

translations.literal: After ninth month, King Huai merged Lu Chen, Xiang Yu's armies and personally led them.
translations.idiomatic: In the following ninth month, King Huai merged the armies of Lu Chen and Xiang Yu under his personal command.

sentences.zh: 以沛公為碭郡長，封武安侯，將碭郡兵。

translations.literal: Made Pei Gong Dang commandery chief, sealed as Marquis of Wuan, led Dang commandery troops.
translations.idiomatic: He appointed Lord Pei as governor of Dang commandery, enfeoffed him as Marquis of Wuan, and put him in command of Dang's troops.

sentences.zh: 以羽為魯公，封長安侯，呂臣為司徒，其父呂青為令尹。

translations.literal: Made Yu Duke of Lu, sealed as Marquis of Chang'an, Lu Chen as Minister of the Masses, his father Lu Qing as Prime Minister.
translations.idiomatic: He made Xiang Yu Duke of Lu and Marquis of Chang'an, appointed Lu Chen as Minister of the Masses, and his father Lu Qing as Prime Minister.

translations.literal: Xiang Liang defeated the Qin army again and grew arrogant. Song Yi advised him against it, but he would not listen. Qin reinforced Zhang Han with additional troops. In the ninth month, Zhang Han attacked Xiang Liang at Dingtao under cover of night with gags in mouths to maintain silence. He inflicted a major defeat and killed Xiang Liang. Continuous rain fell from the seventh through ninth months. Lord Pei and Xiang Yu were in the midst of attacking Chenliu when they heard of Xiang Liang's death. Their troops were terrified, so they joined with General Lu Chen and led their forces east, moving King Huai from Xutai to establish his capital at Pengcheng. Lu Chen's army camped east of Pengcheng, Xiang Yu's army west of Pengcheng, and Lord Pei's army at Dang. Wei Jiu's younger brother Bao proclaimed himself King of Wei. In the following ninth month, King Huai merged the armies of Lu Chen and Xiang Yu under his personal command. He appointed Lord Pei as governor of Dang commandery, enfeoffed him as Marquis of Wuan, and put him in command of Dang's troops. He made Xiang Yu Duke of Lu and Marquis of Chang'an, appointed Lu Chen as Minister of the Masses, and his father Lu Qing as Prime Minister.

sentences.zh: 章邯已破項梁，以為楚地兵不足憂，乃渡河北擊趙王歇，大破之。

translations.literal: Zhang Han having defeated Xiang Liang, thought Chu territory troops not worth worrying about, then crossed north of Yellow River attacked Zhao King Xie, greatly defeated him.
translations.idiomatic: Having defeated Xiang Liang, Zhang Han considered the Chu forces no longer a threat and crossed north of the Yellow River to attack King Xie of Zhao, inflicting a major defeat.

sentences.zh: 歇保鉅鹿城，秦將王離圍之。

translations.literal: Xie defended Julu city, Qin general Wang Li besieged it.
translations.idiomatic: King Xie defended the city of Julu, but Qin general Wang Li besieged it.

sentences.zh: 趙數請救，懷王乃以宋義為上將，項羽為次將，范增為末將，北救趙。

translations.literal: Zhao repeatedly requested rescue, King Huai then made Song Yi supreme general, Xiang Yu deputy general, Fan Zeng rear general, north to rescue Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: Zhao repeatedly appealed for help. King Huai appointed Song Yi as supreme commander, Xiang Yu as deputy commander, and Fan Zeng as rear commander, to march north and rescue Zhao.

translations.literal: Having defeated Xiang Liang, Zhang Han considered the Chu forces no longer a threat and crossed north of the Yellow River to attack King Xie of Zhao, inflicting a major defeat. King Xie defended the city of Julu, but Qin general Wang Li besieged it. Zhao repeatedly appealed for help. King Huai appointed Song Yi as supreme commander, Xiang Yu as deputy commander, and Fan Zeng as rear commander, to march north and rescue Zhao.

sentences.zh: 初，懷王與諸將約，先入定關中者王之。

translations.literal: Originally, King Huai made agreement with various generals, the first to enter and pacify Guanzhong would be made king there.
translations.idiomatic: Originally, King Huai had agreed with his generals that whoever first entered and pacified Guanzhong would be made king there.

sentences.zh: 當是時，秦兵彊，常乘勝逐北，諸將莫利先入關。

translations.literal: At this time, Qin troops strong, constantly took advantage of victory pursued retreating enemy, various generals none saw benefit in entering pass first.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, the Qin forces were strong and constantly pressing their advantage to pursue retreating enemies. None of the generals saw any advantage in being the first to enter the pass.

sentences.zh: 獨羽怨秦破項 梁，奮勢，願與沛公西入關。

translations.literal: Only Yu resented Qin for defeating Xiang Liang, exerted his influence, wished to go west into the pass with Pei Gong.
translations.idiomatic: Only Xiang Yu, resentful that Qin had defeated Xiang Liang, exerted his influence and wished to march west through the pass with Lord Pei.

sentences.zh: 懷王諸老將皆曰：「項羽為人慓悍禍賊，嘗攻襄城，襄城無唣類，所過無不殘滅。

translations.literal: King Huai's various old generals all said: 'Xiang Yu as a person is fierce and violent, a calamitous bandit, once attacked Xiangcheng, Xiangcheng had no survivors, wherever he passed nothing was not completely destroyed.'
translations.idiomatic: All of King Huai's veteran generals said, 'Xiang Yu is fierce and violent, a calamitous bandit. When he attacked Xiangcheng, he left no survivors. Everywhere he goes, he leaves nothing but complete destruction.'

sentences.zh: 且楚數進取，前陳王、項梁皆敗，不如更遣長者扶義 而西，告諭秦父兄。

translations.literal: Moreover Chu repeatedly advanced and took, previously King Chen, Xiang Liang all defeated, not as good as again send elder who upholds righteousness west, inform and persuade Qin fathers and elder brothers.
translations.idiomatic: 'Moreover, Chu has repeatedly advanced and been defeated. King Chen and Xiang Liang both failed. It would be better to send an elder who upholds righteousness to march west and inform the Qin people.'

sentences.zh: 秦父兄苦其主久矣，今誠得長者往，毋侵暴，宜可下。

translations.literal: Qin fathers and elder brothers have suffered under their ruler for a long time, now truly if elder goes, do not invade violently, should be able to surrender.
translations.idiomatic: 'The Qin people have suffered long under their ruler. If we send an elder who does not invade or commit violence, they should surrender.'

sentences.zh: 項羽不可遣，獨沛公素寬大長者。」

translations.literal: Xiang Yu cannot be sent, only Pei Gong is habitually magnanimous and elder.'
translations.idiomatic: 'Xiang Yu cannot be sent. Only Lord Pei has always been magnanimous and virtuous.'

sentences.zh: 卒不許羽，而遣沛公西收陳王、項梁散卒。

translations.literal: In the end did not permit Yu, instead sent Pei Gong west to gather King Chen, Xiang Liang's scattered troops.
translations.idiomatic: In the end, they did not permit Xiang Yu to go, but sent Lord Pei west to gather the scattered troops of King Chen and Xiang Liang.

sentences.zh: 乃道碭至 陽城與杠里，攻秦軍壁，破其二軍。

translations.literal: Then took the Dang road to Yangcheng and Gangli, attacked Qin army fortifications, broke their two armies.
translations.idiomatic: He took the road through Dang to Yangcheng and Gangli, attacked the Qin army fortifications, and broke through two of their armies.

translations.literal: Originally, King Huai had agreed with his generals that whoever first entered and pacified Guanzhong would be made king there. At this time, the Qin forces were strong and constantly pressing their advantage to pursue retreating enemies. None of the generals saw any advantage in being the first to enter the pass. Only Xiang Yu, resentful that Qin had defeated Xiang Liang, exerted his influence and wished to march west through the pass with Lord Pei. All of King Huai's veteran generals said, 'Xiang Yu is fierce and violent, a calamitous bandit. When he attacked Xiangcheng, he left no survivors. Everywhere he goes, he leaves nothing but complete destruction.' 'Moreover, Chu has repeatedly advanced and been defeated. King Chen and Xiang Liang both failed. It would be better to send an elder who upholds righteousness to march west and inform the Qin people.' 'The Qin people have suffered long under their ruler. If we send an elder who does not invade or commit violence, they should surrender.' 'Xiang Yu cannot be sent. Only Lord Pei has always been magnanimous and virtuous.' In the end, they did not permit Xiang Yu to go, but sent Lord Pei west to gather the scattered troops of King Chen and Xiang Liang. He took the road through Dang to Yangcheng and Gangli, attacked the Qin army fortifications, and broke through two of their armies.

sentences.zh: 秦三年十月，齊將田都畔田榮，將兵助項羽救趙。

translations.literal: Qin third year tenth month, Qi general Tian Du rebelled against Tian Rong, led troops to assist Xiang Yu rescue Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: In the tenth month of the third year of Qin, Qi general Tian Du rebelled against Tian Rong and led troops to assist Xiang Yu in rescuing Zhao.

sentences.zh: 沛公攻破東郡尉於成武。

translations.literal: Pei Gong attacked and defeated the Dongjun prefect at Chengwu.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pei attacked and defeated the prefect of Dongjun at Chengwu.

sentences.zh: 十一月，項羽殺宋義，并其兵 渡河，自立為上將軍，諸將黥布等皆屬。

translations.literal: Eleventh month, Xiang Yu killed Song Yi, merged his troops crossed the river, self-established as supreme general, various generals Ying Bu and others all belonged to him.
translations.idiomatic: In the eleventh month, Xiang Yu killed Song Yi, took command of his troops, crossed the river, and proclaimed himself supreme commander. All the generals, including Ying Bu, came under his authority.

sentences.zh: 十二月，沛公引兵至栗，遇剛武侯，奪其軍四千餘人，并之，與魏將皇欣、武滿軍合，攻秦軍，破之。

translations.literal: Twelfth month, Pei Gong led troops to Li, encountered Gangwu Marquis, seized his army more than four thousand people, merged them, combined with Wei generals Huang Xin, Wu Man armies, attacked Qin army, defeated it.
translations.idiomatic: In the twelfth month, Lord Pei led his troops to Li where he encountered the Marquis of Gangwu. He seized more than four thousand of his troops, then joined forces with Wei generals Huang Xin and Wu Man to attack the Qin army and defeat it.

sentences.zh: 故齊王建孫田安下濟 北，從項羽救趙。

translations.literal: Former Qi King Jian's grandson Tian An went down north of Ji, followed Xiang Yu to rescue Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: Tian An, grandson of the former King Jian of Qi, crossed north of the Ji River and joined Xiang Yu to rescue Zhao.

sentences.zh: 羽大破秦軍鉅鹿下，虜王離，走章邯。

translations.literal: Yu greatly defeated Qin army below Julu, captured Wang Li, routed Zhang Han.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu inflicted a major defeat on the Qin army at Julu, captured Wang Li, and put Zhang Han to flight.

translations.literal: In the tenth month of the third year of Qin, Qi general Tian Du rebelled against Tian Rong and led troops to assist Xiang Yu in rescuing Zhao. Lord Pei attacked and defeated the prefect of Dongjun at Chengwu. In the eleventh month, Xiang Yu killed Song Yi, took command of his troops, crossed the river, and proclaimed himself supreme commander. All the generals, including Ying Bu, came under his authority. In the twelfth month, Lord Pei led his troops to Li where he encountered the Marquis of Gangwu. He seized more than four thousand of his troops, then joined forces with Wei generals Huang Xin and Wu Man to attack the Qin army and defeat it. Tian An, grandson of the former King Jian of Qi, crossed north of the Ji River and joined Xiang Yu to rescue Zhao. Xiang Yu inflicted a major defeat on the Qin army at Julu, captured Wang Li, and put Zhang Han to flight.

sentences.zh: 二月，沛公從碭北攻昌邑，遇彭越。

translations.literal: Second month, Pei Gong from north of Dang attacked Changyi, encountered Peng Yue.
translations.idiomatic: In the second month, Lord Pei attacked Changyi from north of Dang and encountered Peng Yue.

sentences.zh: 越助攻昌邑，未下。

translations.literal: Yue helped attack Changyi, did not fall.
translations.idiomatic: Peng Yue helped attack Changyi, but they could not capture it.

sentences.zh: 沛公西過高陽，酈食其為里監門，曰：「諸將過 此者多，吾視沛公大度。」

translations.literal: Pei Gong west passed Gaoyang, Li Yiji was village gatekeeper, said: 'Various generals who passed this place many, I observe Pei Gong has great magnanimity.'
translations.idiomatic: As Lord Pei passed west through Gaoyang, Li Yiji, who was the village gatekeeper, said, 'Many generals have passed through here. I can see that Lord Pei has exceptional magnanimity.'

sentences.zh: 乃求見沛公。

translations.literal: Then requested to see Pei Gong.
translations.idiomatic: He then requested an audience with Lord Pei.

sentences.zh: 沛公方踞床，使兩女子洗。

translations.literal: Pei Gong just then squatting on bed, made two women wash.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pei was lounging on a couch, having two women wash his feet.

sentences.zh: 酈生不拜，長揖曰：「足下必欲誅無道秦，不宜踞見長者。」

translations.literal: Li Sheng did not bow, gave long bow said: 'Your excellency certainly wishes to execute unrighteous Qin, should not lounge to see elders.'
translations.idiomatic: Li Yiji did not bow but gave a slight nod and said, 'If Your Excellency truly wishes to overthrow the tyrannical Qin, you should not receive elders while lounging on a couch.'

sentences.zh: 於是沛公起，攝衣謝之，延上坐。

translations.literal: Thereupon Pei Gong rose, gathered clothes thanked him, invited to upper seat.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pei then rose, straightened his clothes, apologized, and invited Li Yiji to sit in the place of honor.

sentences.zh: 食其說沛公襲陳留。

translations.literal: 食其說沛公襲陳留
translations.idiomatic: 食其說沛公襲陳留

sentences.zh: 沛公以為廣野君，以其弟商為將，將陳留兵。

translations.literal: 沛公以為廣野君 以其弟商為將 將陳留兵
translations.idiomatic: 沛公以為廣野君 以其弟商為將 將陳留兵

sentences.zh: 三月，攻開封，未拔。

translations.literal: 三月 攻開封 未拔
translations.idiomatic: 三月 攻開封 未拔

sentences.zh: 西與秦將楊熊會戰白馬，又戰曲遇東，大破之。

translations.literal: 西與秦將楊熊會戰白馬 又戰曲遇東 大破之
translations.idiomatic: 西與秦將楊熊會戰白馬 又戰曲遇東 大破之

sentences.zh: 楊熊走之滎陽，二世使使斬 之以徇。

translations.literal: 楊熊走之滎陽 二世使使斬 之以徇
translations.idiomatic: 楊熊走之滎陽 二世使使斬 之以徇

sentences.zh: 四月，南攻潁川，屠之。

translations.literal: 四月 南攻潁川 屠之
translations.idiomatic: 四月 南攻潁川 屠之

sentences.zh: 因張良遂略韓地。

translations.literal: 因張良遂略韓地
translations.idiomatic: 因張良遂略韓地

translations.literal: In the second month, Lord Pei attacked Changyi from north of Dang and encountered Peng Yue. Peng Yue helped attack Changyi, but they could not capture it. As Lord Pei passed west through Gaoyang, Li Yiji, who was the village gatekeeper, said, 'Many generals have passed through here. I can see that Lord Pei has exceptional magnanimity.' He then requested an audience with Lord Pei. Lord Pei was lounging on a couch, having two women wash his feet. Li Yiji did not bow but gave a slight nod and said, 'If Your Excellency truly wishes to overthrow the tyrannical Qin, you should not receive elders while lounging on a couch.' Lord Pei then rose, straightened his clothes, apologized, and invited Li Yiji to sit in the place of honor. sentences.zh: 時趙別將司馬卬方欲渡河入關，沛公乃北攻平陰，絕河津。

translations.literal: 時趙別將司馬卬方欲渡河入關 沛公乃北攻平陰 絕河津
translations.idiomatic: 時趙別將司馬卬方欲渡河入關 沛公乃北攻平陰 絕河津

sentences.zh: 南，戰雒陽東，軍不利，從轘轅至陽城，收軍 中馬騎。

translations.literal: 南 戰雒陽東 軍不利 從轘轅至陽城 收軍 中馬騎
translations.idiomatic: 南 戰雒陽東 軍不利 從轘轅至陽城 收軍 中馬騎

sentences.zh: 六月，與南陽守齮戰犨東，大破之。

translations.literal: 六月 與南陽守齮戰犨東 大破之
translations.idiomatic: 六月 與南陽守齮戰犨東 大破之

sentences.zh: 略南陽郡，南陽守走，保城守宛。

translations.literal: 略南陽郡 南陽守走 保城守宛
translations.idiomatic: 略南陽郡 南陽守走 保城守宛

sentences.zh: 沛公引兵過宛西。

translations.literal: 沛公引兵過宛西
translations.idiomatic: 沛公引兵過宛西

sentences.zh: 張良諫曰：「沛公雖欲急入關，秦兵尚眾，距險。

translations.literal: 張良諫曰 沛公雖欲急入關 秦兵尚眾 距險
translations.idiomatic: 張良諫曰 沛公雖欲急入關 秦兵尚眾 距險

sentences.zh: 今不下宛，宛從 後擊，彊秦在前，此危道也。」

translations.literal: 今不下宛 宛從 後擊 彊秦在前 此危道也
translations.idiomatic: 今不下宛 宛從 後擊 彊秦在前 此危道也

sentences.zh: 於是沛公乃夜引軍從他道還，偃旗幟，遲明，圍宛城三匝。

translations.literal: 於是沛公乃夜引軍從他道還 偃旗幟 遲明 圍宛城三匝
translations.idiomatic: 於是沛公乃夜引軍從他道還 偃旗幟 遲明 圍宛城三匝

sentences.zh: 南陽守欲自剄，其舍人陳恢曰：「死未晚也。」

translations.literal: 南陽守欲自剄 其舍人陳恢曰 死未晚也
translations.idiomatic: 南陽守欲自剄 其舍人陳恢曰 死未晚也

sentences.zh: 乃踰城見沛公，曰：「臣 聞足下約先入咸陽者王之，今足下留守宛。

translations.literal: 乃踰城見沛公 曰 臣 聞足下約先入咸陽者王之 今足下留守宛
translations.idiomatic: 乃踰城見沛公 曰 臣 聞足下約先入咸陽者王之 今足下留守宛

sentences.zh: 宛郡縣連城數十，其吏民自以為降必死，故皆堅守乘城。

translations.literal: 宛郡縣連城數十 其吏民自以為降必死 故皆堅守乘城
translations.idiomatic: 宛郡縣連城數十 其吏民自以為降必死 故皆堅守乘城

sentences.zh: 今足下盡日止攻，士死傷者必多；

translations.literal: 今足下盡日止攻 士死傷者必多
translations.idiomatic: 今足下盡日止攻 士死傷者必多

sentences.zh: 引兵去宛，宛必隨足下。

translations.literal: 引兵去宛 宛必隨足下
translations.idiomatic: 引兵去宛 宛必隨足下

sentences.zh: 足下 前則失咸陽之約，後有彊宛之患。

translations.literal: 足下 前則失咸陽之約 後有彊宛之患
translations.idiomatic: 足下 前則失咸陽之約 後有彊宛之患

sentences.zh: 為足下計，莫若約降，封其守，因使止守，引其甲卒與之西。

translations.literal: 為足下計 莫若約降 封其守 因使止守 引其甲卒與之西
translations.idiomatic: 為足下計 莫若約降 封其守 因使止守 引其甲卒與之西

sentences.zh: 諸城未下者，聞聲爭開門而待足下，足下通行無所累。」

translations.literal: 諸城未下者 聞聲爭開門而待足下 足下通行無所累
translations.idiomatic: 諸城未下者 聞聲爭開門而待足下 足下通行無所累

sentences.zh: 沛公曰： 「善。」

translations.literal: 沛公曰  善
translations.idiomatic: 沛公曰 善

sentences.zh: 七月，南陽守齮降，封為殷侯，封陳恢千戶。

translations.literal: 七月 南陽守齮降 封為殷侯 封陳恢千戶
translations.idiomatic: 七月 南陽守齮降 封為殷侯 封陳恢千戶

sentences.zh: 引兵西，無不下者。

translations.literal: 引兵西 無不下者
translations.idiomatic: 引兵西 無不下者

sentences.zh: 至丹水，高武侯鰓、襄侯王陵降。

translations.literal: 至丹水 高武侯鰓、襄侯王陵降
translations.idiomatic: 至丹水 高武侯鰓、襄侯王陵降

sentences.zh: 還攻胡陽，遇番君別將梅鋗，與偕攻析、酈，皆降。

translations.literal: 還攻胡陽 遇番君別將梅鋗 與偕攻析、酈 皆降
translations.idiomatic: 還攻胡陽 遇番君別將梅鋗 與偕攻析、酈 皆降

sentences.zh: 所 過毋得鹵掠，秦民喜。

translations.literal: 所 過毋得鹵掠 秦民喜
translations.idiomatic: 所 過毋得鹵掠 秦民喜

sentences.zh: 遣魏人甯昌使秦。
